metadata.title: TikTok is the latest example of the U.S. government taking a cut of business deals

content.text: Sept. 26, 2025, 11:46 AM EDTBy Akayla GardnerIn his 2000 book, “The America We Deserve,” Donald Trump wrote that “what’s worked beautifully throughout American history is the freemarket economy.”By definition, such a system is characterized by minimal government involvement; absent the kind of bureaucratic influence that stifles competition. For capitalists, it’s the hallmark of America’s economic prosperity. But, in Trump’s second term as president, his White House has pushed the bounds of a limited intervention approach to the private sector, a system once championed by Republicans and the president himself. The ministration has taken on an unusually significant role in arranging business deals and, in an increasing number of cases, the government is even taking a piece of the pie.That’s a kind of classic view of a real estate dealmaker, as opposed to a statesman and steward of the U.S. economy.”Scott Lincicome, vice president of economics and tre at the Cato InstituteThe latest example is expected to come in the form of what Trump called a “tremendous fee” the U.S. will collect for its part in negotiating an agreement to spin off the Chinese social media app TikTok into a U.S.-based entity. The Wall Street Journal estimates that it will be a multibillion-dollar payment — a hefty amount for direct discussions with President Xi Jinping and other Chinese officials.Last month, the ministration also took a nearly 10% stake in Intel by converting Biden-era grants into stock. Chipmakers Nvidia and AMD promised the government 15% of their revenues from sales of chips in China. ditionally, the Pentagon recently bought $400 million in stock from a critical-minerals mining company, and is considering acquiring equity in defense giant Lockheed Martin, too.The moves are driven by “a consistent belief” in the Trump ministration that the government should get a cut of any “major deal that comes across the president’s desk,” said Scott Lincicome, vice president of economics and tre at the Cato Institute. “That’s a kind of classic view of a real estate dealmaker, as opposed to a statesman and steward of the U.S. economy.”The Nightcap: Are CEOs and their companies feeling pressure from Trump?09:46Trump officials argue that the agreements have been in the country’s national interest because of national security risks, especially in critical industries like vanced technology. As for TikTok, a bipartisan law required its parent company, ByteDance, to divest from its American operations or face a ban over data privacy concerns.Yet, the string of deals raises questions about whether certain companies have a leg up in competition, such as for prized government contracts, or favor navigating federal regulations compared to their counterparts.The White House downplays its entanglements with businesses and plays up its other deregulatory efforts. One ministration official pointed to a Council of Economic visers report that concluded that eliminating the Biden ministration’s regulatory policies would spur enough economic growth to reduce the deficit by $1.1 trillion to $2.9 trillion over the next dece.In general, the American system is supposed to say that the government merely sets the rules; it doesn’t pick the winners and losers.” John Rosen, economics professor at the University of New HavenIn a statement, White House spokesperson Kush Desai said, “Washington, D.C.’s blind commitment to consensus orthodoxy that ignored the realities of the world is exactly why Americans and America were left behind: look no further than lopsided ‘free’ tre arrangements that let foreign cheating decimate our industrial base. The ministration is simultaneously pushing the free market policies — such as rapid deregulation and working-class tax cuts — that do work while rectifying the America Last policies that haven’t worked to safeguard our national and economic security.” By most accounts, the volume and scope of such deals that Trump has pursued in office are unprecedented. “When you have a perpetual stake in a company, it just fundamentally changes the dynamic,” Lincicome said. “We’re not talking about a one-off deal.”“All of these deals,” Lincicome continued, “have a pain point or a leverage point that really puts success or failure at discretion of the president himself, and the Trump ministration increasingly appears willing to use that leverage to exploit that pain point to achieve whatever they want.”Some leverage points include subsidies and loans approved under his predecessor, Joe Biden, which Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told lawmakers this summer he would review. “We should get an equity state for our money,” Lutnick told CNBC, “inste of just giving grants away.”Trump min reveals deal to keep TikTok in the U.S.05:37Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, supported the ministration taking equity in Intel. Meanwhile, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., who backed a similar concept in 2022, criticized the deal. “What is the American public getting from this deal?” she asked in a letter to Lutnick. “An extremely risky investment.”In another deal, Nippon Steel required approval from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or CFIUS, for its bid to purchase U.S. Steel. The president issued an order asking CFIUS to launch a new review before later announcing plans for the transaction. The ministration received a symbolic “golden share” as part of approving the acquisition, allowing Trump officials to wield wide-ranging veto powers over critical company decisions. Recently, the White House said it halted the company’s decision to close a plant in Illinois.United Steelworkers International President David McCall said Trump “has assumed a startling degree of personal power over a corporation,” describing the agreement. The firm’s tether to the government likely will continue after Trump leaves office and it’s unclear if, and when, it ever expires. Justin Wolfers, an economist at the University of Michigan, said that the arrangements amount to “crony capitalism,” in which relationships with bureaucrats influence normal market conditions. He argued that officials could use “soft pressure,” with the Intel deal, for example, to convince companies “to buy computer chips that they didn’t want to buy.” For competitors, “anyone who puts pressure on you to buy a set of computer chips that you didn’t otherwise want to buy is making your business worse,” Wolfers ded.The U.S. government has previously taken steps to stabilize industry during wartimes and recessions, such as the 2008 financial crisis, but usually with the intent to eventually release firms from temporary government control. The Trump ministration is attempting to do just that by putting mortgage guarantors Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac back on the market.According to John Rosen, an economics professor at the University of New Haven, other presidents have wielded their power to put their weight on the scale of business deals for their friends, such as Oracle’s Larry Ellison, a Trump ally and an investor in the TikTok deal. “In general, the American system is supposed to say that the government merely sets the rules; it doesn’t pick the winners and losers,” Rosen explained. “But as with all things Trump, he’s more flamboyant and visible about it.”Akayla GardnerAkayla Gardner is a White House correspondent for MSNBC.

data-taboola-target="read-more" data-testid="article-body"><div class="article-body__grid--container"><div class="article-body__section"><div class="article-body layout-grid-item layout-grid-item--with-gutter-s-only grid-col-10-m grid-col-push-1-m grid-col-6-xl grid-col-push-2-xl article-body--custom-column"></div></div><div class="article-body__section layout-grid-container article-body__last-section article-body__first-section"><div class="article-body layout-grid-item layout-grid-item--with-gutter-s-only grid-col-10-m grid-col-push-1-m grid-col-6-xl grid-col-push-2-xl article-body--custom-column"><section class="mb7"><div class="styles_contentTimestampWithSource__FIhli" data-testid="article-body-timestamp"><time class="relative z-1" content="2025-09-26T15:46:07.724Z" data-testid="article-body-timestamp__timestamp" datetime="2025-09-26T15:46:07.724Z">Sept. 26, 2025, 11:46 AM EDT</time></div><div class="relative"><div class="article-inline-byline" data-activity-map="inline-byline-article-top" data-testid="article-byline-inline">By <span class="byline-name" data-testid="byline-name"><a href="https://www.msnbc.com/author/akayla-gardner-ncpn1312627">Akayla Gardner</a></span></div></div></section><div class="article-body__content"><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-6898fa">In his 2000 book, “The America We Deserve,” <a href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_America_We_Deserve/" target="_blank">Donald Trump wrote</a> that “what’s worked beautifully throughout American history is the freemarket economy.”</p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-26d75b">By definition, such a system is characterized by minimal government involvement; absent the kind of bureaucratic influence that stifles competition. For capitalists, it’s the hallmark of America’s economic prosperity. </p><div class="ad dn-print ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd" data-testid="ad__container"><div data-active-tab="true" data-mps="true" data-offset-viewport="100" data-render-on-view="true" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-slot="boxinline" data-targeting="{}" data-testid="ad__container__inner"></div></div><div id="taboolaReadMoreBelow"></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-eb629a">But, in Trump’s second term as president, his White House has pushed the bounds of a limited intervention approach to the private sector, a system once championed by Republicans and the president himself. The administration has taken on <a href="https://www.msnbc.com/ana-cabrera-reports/watch/murdoch-family-larry-ellison-among-billionaires-expected-to-play-role-in-trump-s-tiktok-deal-248334917764" target="_blank">an unusually significant role in arranging business deals</a> and, in an increasing number of cases, the government is even taking a piece of the pie.</p><div class="pullquote pullquote--small" data-testid="pullquote-small" id="anchor-fcd49b"><p class="pullquote__quote" data-testid="pullquote-quote">That’s a kind of classic view of a real estate dealmaker, as opposed to a statesman and steward of the U.S. economy.”</p><p class="pullquote__attribution"><cite class="pullquote__cite" data-testid="pullquote-attribution">Scott Lincicome, vice president of economics and trade at the Cato Institute</cite><span class="pullquote__quip" data-testid="pullquote-quip"></span></p></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-91a4b5">The latest example is expected to come in the form of <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/19/business/media/trump-china-tiktok-deal.html" target="_blank">what Trump called</a> a “tremendous fee” the U.S. will collect for its part in negotiating an agreement to spin off the <a href="https://www.msnbc.com/way-too-early/watch/trump-admin-reveals-deal-to-keep-tiktok-in-the-u-s-248139333729" target="_blank">Chinese social media app TikTok </a>into a U.S.-based entity. The Wall Street Journal estimates that it will be a <a href="https://www.wsj.com/business/deals/u-s-government-expected-to-get-multibillion-dollar-fee-in-tiktok-deal-685e3944?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=ASWzDAj5pH7XZpji-UBNXwWQXACcFC3j_oJJyrgnyyvQzhURsa9vx9HbmGOfsb1c9yc%3D&gaa_ts=68d5b91d&gaa_sig=YslqCKKbtJ_flzwZ9BAtUJGmlmfRZ7vtwVX5hWzmSZkTlsGu-m1KyR42GinHRHlBrY1vMQq7KfTFcSDjh-Bptw%3D%3D" target="_blank">multibillion-dollar payment</a> — a hefty amount for direct discussions with President Xi Jinping and other Chinese officials.</p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-3c6b47">Last month, the administration also took a nearly 10% stake in Intel by converting Biden-era grants into stock. Chipmakers <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2025/08/10/nvidia-amd-15percent-of-china-chip-sales-revenues-to-us-ft-reports.html" target="_blank">Nvidia and AMD</a> promised the government 15% of their revenues from sales of chips in China. Additionally, the Pentagon recently bought <a href="https://investors.mpmaterials.com/investor-news/news-details/2025/MP-Materials-Announces-Transformational-Public-Private-Partnership-with-the-Department-of-Defense-to-Accelerate-U-S--Rare-Earth-Magnet-Independence/default.aspx" target="_blank">$400 million</a> in stock from a critical-minerals mining company, and is considering acquiring equity in defense giant <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2025/08/26/trump-pentagon-equity-stakes-in-defense-contractors.html" target="_blank">Lockheed Martin</a>, too.</p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-900216">The moves are driven by “a consistent belief” in the Trump administration that the government should get a cut of any “major deal that comes across the president’s desk,” said Scott Lincicome, vice president of economics and trade at the Cato Institute. “That’s a kind of classic view of a real estate dealmaker, as opposed to a statesman and steward of the U.S. economy.”</p><section class="inline-video inline-video--in-body" data-testid="inline-video" id="anchor-c3a753"><div class="inline-video__background"><div class="inline-video__player"><div tabindex="-1"></div><div data-activity-map="social-share-links-inline-share" data-testid="social-share-menu"><li class="styles_item__mbZKv styles_facebook__9umol" data-testid="social-share-facebook"><a aria-label="Share to rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><span aria-hidden="true" class="icon icon-twitter"></span></a></li><li class="styles_item__mbZKv" data-testid="social-share-email"><a aria-label="Email link" class="icon icon-share-email"></span></a></li><li class="dn db-m share-list__copy_icon styles_item__mbZKv styles_copy__qdnAE" data-testid="social-share-copy"><button aria-label="Copy link" class="styles_button__ZavSV" type="button"><span aria-hidden="true" class="icon icon-link"></span></button><div class="styles_copyTooltip__BbAu3"><span class="icon icon-alt-check"></span></div></li><li class="styles_item__mbZKv styles_sms__cqTbv" data-testid="social-share-sms"><a aria-label="Share to SMS" class="styles_link__zhvMF" href="sms:?&body=The Nightcap: Are CEOs and their companies feeling pressure from Trump? via msnbc - https://www.msnbc.com/11th-hour/watch/the-nightcap-are-ceos-and-their-companies-feeling-pressure-from-trump-247990341978" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><span aria-hidden="true" class="icon icon-sms"></span></a></li></ul></div></div><div class="styles_overlayText__nQD91" data-testid="overlay-text"><div class="styles_title__4fzZQ"><a href="https://www.msnbc.com/11th-hour/watch/the-nightcap-are-ceos-and-their-companies-feeling-pressure-from-trump-247990341978">The Nightcap: Are CEOs and their companies feeling pressure from Trump?</a></div><div class="styles_detail__IKiBW"><span>09:46</span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-695c85">Trump officials argue that the agreements have been in the country’s national interest because of national security risks, especially in critical industries like advanced technology. As for TikTok, <a href="https://www.msnbc.com/top-stories/latest/tiktok-ban-federal-court-decision-rcna183181" target="_blank">a bipartisan law</a> required its parent company, ByteDance, to divest from its American operations or face a ban over data privacy concerns.</p><div class="ad dn-print ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd" data-testid="ad__container"><div data-active-tab="true" data-mps="true" data-offset-viewport="100" data-render-on-view="true" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-slot="boxinline" data-targeting="{}" data-testid="ad__container__inner"></div></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-b3f6b4">Yet, the string of deals raises questions about whether certain companies have a leg up in competition, such as for prized government contracts, or favor navigating federal regulations compared to their counterparts.</p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-786d48">The White House downplays its entanglements with businesses and plays up its other deregulatory efforts. One administration official pointed to <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/The-Economic-Benefits-of-Current-Deregulatory-Efforts.pdf" target="_blank">a Council of Economic Advisers report</a> that concluded that eliminating the Biden administration’s regulatory policies would spur enough economic growth to reduce the deficit by $1.1 trillion to $2.9 trillion over the next decade.</p><div class="pullquote pullquote--small" data-testid="pullquote-small" id="anchor-3fcab0"><p class="pullquote__quote" data-testid="pullquote-quote">In general, the American system is supposed to say that the government merely sets the rules; it doesn’t pick the winners and losers.” </p><p class="pullquote__attribution"><cite class="pullquote__cite" data-testid="pullquote-attribution">John Rosen, economics professor at the University of New Haven</cite><span class="pullquote__quip" data-testid="pullquote-quip"></span></p></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-3e7ad4">In a statement, White House spokesperson Kush Desai said, “Washington, D.C.’s blind commitment to consensus orthodoxy that ignored the realities of the world is exactly why Americans and America were left behind: look no further than lopsided ‘free’ trade arrangements that let foreign cheating decimate our industrial base. The Administration is simultaneously pushing the free market policies — such as rapid deregulation and working-class tax cuts — that do work while rectifying the America Last policies that haven’t worked to safeguard our national and economic security.” </p><div class="recommended-intersection-ref" data-activity-map="recommended-article-body-recommended" data-testid="recommended-wrapper"></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-9f7eb0">By most accounts, the volume and scope of such deals that Trump has pursued in office are unprecedented. “When you have a perpetual stake in a company, it just fundamentally changes the dynamic,” Lincicome said. “We’re not talking about a one-off deal.”</p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-211897">“All of these deals,” Lincicome continued, “have a pain point or a leverage point that really puts success or failure at discretion of the president himself, and the Trump administration increasingly appears willing to use that leverage to exploit that pain point to achieve whatever they want.”</p><div class="ad dn-print ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd" data-testid="ad__container"><div data-active-tab="true" data-mps="true" data-offset-viewport="100" data-render-on-view="true" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-slot="boxinline" data-targeting="{}" data-testid="ad__container__inner"></div></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-97353b">Some leverage points include subsidies and loans approved under his predecessor, Joe Biden, which Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told lawmakers this summer he would review. “We should get an equity state for our money,” <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2025/08/19/lutnick-intel-stock-chips-trump.html" target="_blank">Lutnick told CNBC,</a> “instead of just giving grants away.”</p><section class="inline-video inline-video--in-body" data-testid="inline-video" id="anchor-86bb10"><div class="inline-video__background"><div class="inline-video__player"><div tabindex="-1"></div><div href="https://www.msnbc.com/way-too-early/watch/trump-admin-reveals-deal-to-keep-tiktok-in-the-u-s-248139333729">Trump admin reveals deal to keep TikTok in the U.S.</a></div><div class="styles_detail__IKiBW"><span>05:37</span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-2532ae">Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-senator-sanders-favors-trump-plan-take-stake-intel-other-chipmakers-2025-08-20/" target="_blank">supported the administration</a> taking equity in Intel. Meanwhile, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., who backed a similar concept in 2022, <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/emilybaker-white/2025/09/04/elizabeth-warren-decries-trumps-intel-deal-as-an-extremely-risky-investment/" target="_blank">criticized the deal</a>. “What is the American public getting from this deal?” she asked in a letter to Lutnick. “An extremely risky investment.”</p><div class="recommended-intersection-ref" data-activity-map="recommended-article-body-recommended" data-testid="recommended-wrapper"></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-a59981">In another deal, Nippon Steel required approval from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or CFIUS, for its bid to purchase U.S. Steel. The president issued an order asking CFIUS to launch a new review before later announcing plans for the transaction. The administration received a symbolic “golden share” as part of approving the acquisition, allowing Trump officials to wield wide-ranging veto powers over critical company decisions. Recently, the White House said it <a href="https://apnews.com/article/us-steel-trump-nippon-steel-granite-city-7d9acc7f1a1b08b971b374c40574beec" target="_blank">halted the company’s decision</a> to close a plant in Illinois.</p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-40bc40">United Steelworkers International President David McCall said Trump “has assumed a startling degree of personal power over a corporation,” describing the agreement. The firm’s tether to the government likely will continue after Trump leaves office and it’s unclear if, and when, it ever expires. </p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-c5a346">Justin Wolfers, an economist at the University of Michigan, said that the arrangements amount to “crony capitalism,” in which  relationships with bureaucrats influence normal market conditions. He argued that officials could use “soft pressure,” with the Intel deal, for example, to convince companies “to buy computer chips that they didn’t want to buy.” For competitors, “anyone who puts pressure on you to buy a set of computer chips that you didn’t otherwise want to buy is making your business worse,” Wolfers added.</p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-743d63">The U.S. government has previously taken steps to stabilize industry during wartimes and recessions, such as the 2008 financial crisis, but usually with the intent to eventually release firms from temporary government control. The Trump administration is attempting to do just that by putting mortgage guarantors<strong> </strong>Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac back on the market.</p><div class="ad dn-print ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd" data-testid="ad__container"><div data-active-tab="true" data-mps="true" data-offset-viewport="100" data-render-on-view="true" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-slot="boxinline" data-targeting="{}" data-testid="ad__container__inner"></div></div><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-a4f08e">According to John Rosen, an economics professor at the University of New Haven, other presidents have wielded their power to put their weight on the scale of business deals for their friends, such as Oracle’s Larry Ellison, a Trump ally and an investor in the TikTok deal. </p><p class="body-graf" id="anchor-482912">“In general, the American system is supposed to say that the government merely sets the rules; it doesn’t pick the winners and losers,” Rosen explained. “But as with all things Trump, he’s more flamboyant and visible about it.”</p></div><div class="article-body__content"><div class="expanded-byline-contributors articleBylineContainer"><div class="expanded-byline For capitalists, it’s the hallmark of America’s economic prosperity. ","But, in Trump’s second term as president, his White House has pushed the bounds of a limited intervention approach to the private sector, a system once championed by Republicans and the president himself. The administration has taken on an unusually significant role in arranging business deals and, in an increasing number of cases, the government is even taking a piece of the pie.","The latest example is expected to come in the form of what Trump called a “tremendous fee” the U.S. will collect for its part in negotiating an agreement to spin off the Chinese social media app TikTok into a U.S.-based entity. The Wall Street Journal estimates that it will be a multibillion-dollar payment — a hefty amount for direct discussions with President Xi Jinping and other Chinese officials.","Last month, the administration also took a nearly 10% stake in Intel by converting Biden-era grants into stock. Chipmakers Nvidia and AMD promised the government 15% of their revenues from sales of chips in China. Additionally, the Pentagon recently bought $400 million in stock from a critical-minerals mining company, and is considering acquiring equity in defense giant Lockheed Martin, too.","The moves are driven by “a consistent belief” in the Trump administration that the government should get a cut of any “major deal that comes across the president’s desk,” said Scott Lincicome, vice president of economics and trade at the Cato Institute. “That’s a kind of classic view of a real estate dealmaker, as opposed to a statesman and steward of the U.S. economy.”","Trump officials argue that the agreements have been in the country’s national interest because of national security risks, especially in critical industries like advanced technology. As for TikTok, a bipartisan law required its parent company, ByteDance, to divest from its American operations or face a ban over data privacy concerns.","Yet, the string of deals raises questions about whether certain companies have a leg up in competition, such as for prized government contracts, or favor navigating federal regulations compared to their counterparts.","The White House downplays its entanglements with businesses and plays up its other deregulatory efforts. One administration official pointed to a Council of Economic Advisers report that concluded that eliminating the Biden administration’s regulatory policies would spur enough economic growth to reduce the deficit by $1.1 trillion to $2.9 trillion over the next decade.","In a statement, White House spokesperson Kush Desai said, “Washington, D.C.’s blind commitment to consensus orthodoxy that ignored the realities of the world is exactly why Americans and America were left behind: look no further than lopsided ‘free’ trade arrangements that let foreign cheating decimate our industrial base. The Administration is simultaneously pushing the free market policies — such as rapid deregulation and working-class tax cuts — that do work while rectifying the America Last policies that haven’t worked to safeguard our national and economic security.” ","By most accounts, the volume and scope of such deals that Trump has pursued in office are unprecedented. “When you have a perpetual stake in a company, it just fundamentally changes the dynamic,” Lincicome said. “We’re not talking about a one-off deal.”","“All of these deals,” Lincicome continued, “have a pain point or a leverage point that really puts success or failure at discretion of the president himself, and the Trump administration increasingly appears willing to use that leverage to exploit that pain point to achieve whatever they want.”","Some leverage points include subsidies and loans approved under his predecessor, Joe Biden, which Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told lawmakers this summer he would review. “We should get an equity state for our money,” Lutnick told CNBC, “instead of just giving grants away.”","Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, supported the administration taking equity in Intel. Meanwhile, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., who backed a similar concept in 2022, criticized the deal. “What is the American public getting from this deal?” she asked in a letter to Lutnick. “An extremely risky investment.”","In another deal, Nippon Steel required approval from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or CFIUS, for its bid to purchase U.S. Steel. The president issued an order asking CFIUS to launch a new review before later announcing plans for the transaction. The administration received a symbolic “golden share” as part of approving the acquisition, allowing Trump officials to wield wide-ranging veto powers over critical company decisions. Recently, the White House said it halted the company’s decision to close a plant in Illinois.","United Steelworkers International President David McCall said Trump “has assumed a startling degree of personal power over a corporation,” describing the agreement. The firm’s tether to the government likely will continue after Trump leaves office and it’s unclear if, and when, it ever expires. ","Justin Wolfers, an economist at the University of Michigan, said that the arrangements amount to “crony capitalism,” in which  relationships with bureaucrats influence normal market conditions. He argued that officials could use “soft pressure,” with the Intel deal, for example, to convince companies “to buy computer chips that they didn’t want to buy.” For competitors, “anyone who puts pressure on you to buy a set of computer chips that you didn’t otherwise want to buy is making your business worse,” Wolfers added.","The U.S. government has previously taken steps to stabilize industry during wartimes and recessions, such as the 2008 financial crisis, but usually with the intent to eventually release firms from temporary government control. The Trump administration is attempting to do just that by putting mortgage guarantors Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac back on the market.","According to John Rosen, an economics professor at the University of New Haven, other presidents have wielded their power to put their weight on the scale of business deals for their friends, such as Oracle’s Larry Ellison, a Trump ally and an investor in the TikTok deal. ","“In general, the American system is supposed to say that the government merely sets the rules; it doesn’t pick the winners and losers,” Rosen explained. “But as with all things Trump, he’s more flamboyant and visible about it.”"]},"documentTracing":{"currentMessageId":{"id":"5e0be497-ba18-49d5-81e3-700f86410f5b","updatedDate":"Fri Sep 26 2025 15:56:24 GMT+0000
